docs.lead_paragraph: Vernon Scott, a retired 78-year-old reporter for United Press International who covered Hollywood for decades, still recalls the golden era of the 1940's and 1950's. The town's powerful columnists, Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons, would have trucks outside their offices to haul away Christmas gifts of whiskey, jewelry and clothes, given by studios. Even a less powerful columnist would get his share of the holiday cheer: Mr. Scott said one columnist would have a studio refurnish each room of his home. ''The good old days,'' Mr. Scott said with a laugh.

headline.main: 3 Journalists Resign in Clash Of Old and New In Hollywood

docs.lead_paragraph: In processing medical payments, the longstanding promise of computer networks has been their ability to convey insurance claims and other billing records, without need of the paperwork and documents that can be delayed in the mail or waylaid in some bureaucrat's file drawer. But for Peter Waegemann, that promise is a threat to insurance companies, hospitals, doctors and government agencies -- unless the parties in an electronic transaction can be sure of one another's identities. Otherwise, he says, all parties could leave themselves open to fraud or legal liabilities in the event of an error or a network intruder.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The decline in chronic illness among the elderly (news article, May 8) shows that dire predictions of Medicare's insolvency wrongly ignored scientific innovation. Forecasters based their alarming projections on the cost of caring for an elderly person today, ignoring how medicine will change. It would have made as much sense to count the number of iron lungs in use in the 1950's and predict how many more would be needed in future decades.

docs.lead_paragraph: Elected officials, hospital administrators, doctors and union leaders across the country are seeking to reverse a new Medicare policy that they say will slash billions of dollars from the health care industry and force cutbacks in critical hospital services. Nationwide, hospitals will lose roughly $1.6 billion annually once the new Medicare cuts are in place, by October 2002, according to industry officials. The bulk of the cuts will directly affect the nation's teaching hospitals, many of them in New York and other cities, including Boston, Philadelphia, Houston, Atlanta, Pittsburgh and Baltimore. They are likely to result in more crowded clinics and emergency rooms as well as higher charges to private insurers and to patients themselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stock Rally in April Left Many Hedge Funds Behind For many individual investors, the Federal Reserve's surprise rate cut last month and the rally in stocks was welcome news after a prolonged drought. But many hedge fund managers were betting on continued market declines and badly trailed the broader market. Hedge funds are designed to weather bear markets, in part by selling short, which involves borrowing shares from a broker and betting that they will decline in value. Short selling, though, did not help in April, and many hedge funds also lagged because they had stashed away a lot of cash. [Page C7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Every few days, another tearful family arrived at coroner's court in nearby Tameside, anxiously awaiting the official proclamation that a loved one who had died years before -- usually a woman, usually elderly -- had been the victim of murder. Everyone knows who committed the crime. He was a trusted citizen of Hyde, a family doctor who cared for its townspeople with a dedication that won him widespread adoration. But he was also a man who hid a horrible secret: Harold Frederick Shipman, 55, was England's -- and perhaps the world's -- most prolific serial killer.
